description: From Middle English tennys, teneys, tenis, from Old French tenez, second-person plural imperative of tenir (“to hold”).

entries.meaning: (sports) A sport played by two players (or four in doubles), who alternately strike the ball over a net using racquets.

examples: We go about to parties in the daytime as usual, teas and tennises […]

entries.meaning: (obsolete) An earlier game in which a ball is driven to and fro, or kept in motion by striking it with a racquet or with the open hand.

verbs.description: tennis (third-person singular simple present tennises, present participle tennising, simple past and past participle tennised)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To drive backward and forward like a tennis ball.
examples: they shall have Intelligence or Espial upon the Enemy, will so drive him from one side to another, and tennis him amongst them
